newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak govt seeks quick sale of fridge maker Calex.
newsitem.headline: Slovak govt seeks quick sale of fridge maker Calex.

text.p: The Slovak government hopes to complete the sale of state-owned home appliance producer Calex s.p. by April, a senior official said on Monday.
"We are currently negotiating with four companies interested in buying Calex, three of which are foreign," Frantisek Kubica, head of the Economic Ministry's engineering department, told Reuters.
"We really need a quick solution. Ideally, the matter should be completed by the end of April this year."
He would not disclose the names of the bidders.
Kubica said the ministry would seek to sell the entire 100 percent it holds in Calex in one deal. "It would not be good to split the company into lots of pieces with different owners," Kubica said.
The book value of the company is some six billion crowns, but the ministry said the final price would depend on the production programme a buyer would propose.
"If they introduce a perspective programme ensuring no radical layoffs, the price will, of course, be lower," he said.
South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co Ltd cancelled its prepurchase right for Calex last November, saying it was no longer interested in producing white goods, Kubica said.
"We accepted Samsung's withdrawal, but on condition that it would sell its stake in the joint-venture with Calex to the state," he said, adding that Samsung had accepted this.
In 1991, Samsung and Calex formed a joint-venture to manufacture refrigerators and freezers in which the South Korean firm holds a 44.8 percent stake. Samsung originally wanted to buy Calex outright.
Calex was forced to suspend production for one week on February 10 due to liquidity problems. It had to postpone payment of January wages for its 2,400 employees due to a lack of financial resources.
The company's debts are estimated at some eight billion crowns, most of which are guaranteed by the state.
Calex is on the government list of strategic companies, which should not be privatised at all or in which the state will keep a veto right over key decisions.
But Kubica said that "the company's strategic statute ends with the state guarantees for its loans".
"Though these are being repaid, the government is considering taking part in restructuring the company's debts," he added, but did not elaborate.
